awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Gravity Wave-Airglow Interactions in Multiple Emission Layers
awd_abstract_narration:
Perturbations in the neutral density in the Earth's middle and upper atmosphere known as gravity waves (GWs) are thought to be an important driver of physical and chemical processes in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) atmospheric region. GWs influence tidal and planetary wave dynamics as well as general circulation and transport processes across many atmospheric layers. The goal of this project is to investigate the interaction of GWs and airglow, faint optical emission emitted by atoms and molecules in MLT during the night. Through this, a better understanding of the impact of GWs on chemical species in the MLT region will be achieved. This project will conduct observations in multiple airglow layers with a chain of airglow imagers near the Andes Lidar Observatory (ALO) in Chile, a well-known GW "hotspot". This will be complemented by observations with the collocated lidar and meteor radar, satellites, and results from time-dependent, nonlinear atmospheric models. This project will promote education by supporting a graduate student and an undergraduate student and contribute to broadening participation by supporting the team that includes members from underrepresented groups.

The work will involve characterization of GW activity near ALO based on the imaging airglow data and comparison of simulation results of GW-airglow interactions with imaging observations. Recent modeling results using a 2D, nonlinear, time-dependent OH Chemistry-Dynamics (OHCD) model and a Multiple-Airglow Chemistry-Dynamics (MACD) models have shown that a transient dissipating GW packet can induce significant variations in the concentrations of the minor species, in the airglow intensity, and in exothermal heating. The variations appear to be aperiodic but are often mistaken for long-period waves. These are secular variations which are a result of a net cycle-averaged transport of chemically-active minor species. The project will simulate secular variations in airglow causes by GWs by using a model of GW propagation together with airglow chemistry models, OHCD and MACD, in conjunction with optical, lidar, and meteor radar observations at ALO complemented by spacecraft data from SABER and SCIAMACHY.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The growing concern over global warming and climate change has sparked interest in understanding how different factors affect our atmosphere. Our research delves into the dynamics of airglow temperatures, meteors, and sodium layers, seeking to uncover how they respond to solar cycle variations, geomagnetic activity, and geomagnetic storms. By deciphering these relationships, we aim to discern the relative impact of natural phenomena versus human activities.

We developed MADAME (Machine-learning Approach to Detecting and Analyzing Meteor Echoes) employs advanced machine-learning techniques to process radar data. Using the YOLOv4 CNN model, it accurately detects meteor head and trail echoes, identifying over 80 per minute. MADAME autonomously processes data in interferometer mode, revealing meteor shower sources and velocities. It finds that half of meteors move in inclined orbits and those with trails likely originate from shower sources. These results demonstrate the power of machine learning in radar signal processing for meteor research.

We also investigated the link between atmospheric sodium concentration and its Meteoric Input Function (MIF). Using data from Colorado State University (CSU) Lidar and Andes Lidar Observatory (ALO), alongside a new numerical model focusing on sodium chemistry in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) region, we observed seasonal sodium density fluctuations at CSU, but discrepancies at ALO, near the South Atlantic Anomaly (SAA) region. Despite fewer observations at ALO, our model highlights the significance of meteoric uptake in determining sodium concentration in MLT, emphasizing its role over NaHCO3 dimerization. These insights enhance our understanding of MLT dynamics, aiding future research and model development for improved atmospheric comprehension.

Our findings not only contribute valuable insights to the scientific community but also address the curiosity of the general public, offering a clearer picture of how our climate is evolving. Through comprehensive analysis encompassing model simulations and observations from both ground-based and satellite sources, our project sheds light on the intricate interplay between various influences, providing crucial information on atmospheric dynamics and their implications for climate change mitigation and adaptation efforts. Overall, during the entire duration of this project, nine journal papers were published reporting our findings and one graduate student complete his PhD. degree.
